task.title: Removing Oil-Based Stains
task.shortdesc: Instructions for removing oil-based stains from cotton or cotton-blend fabrics.

prereq.p:
Materials needed:
Heavy-duty laundry detergent
Enzyme-based stain remover (spray or gel)
Cornstarch or talcum powder
Soft-bristled brush
Dull knife, spoon
Small bowl
Paper towels or napkins
WD-40 (for set-in stains)

step.cmd: Remove excess oil from the fabric

choices.choice: For fresh stains without solid residue, blot the area with a paper towel or napkin.
For solid residue, gently lift it with a dull knife or spoon.

step.cmd: For older or set-in stains, apply a small amount of WD-40 with a cotton swab.
Generously apply cornstarch or talcum powder to the stain to absorb as much oil as possible.
Allow the powder to sit on the stain for about 15 minutes to fully absorb the oil
Brush the powder away with a soft-bristled brush.
Pretreat the stain with an enzyme-based stain remover spray or gel.

info.note: If an enzyme-based remover is unavailable, use heavy-duty liquid detergent and work it into the fabric with your fingers or a soft-bristled brush.

step.cmd: Let the stain remover sit on the stain for at least 15-30 minutes to allow enzymes to break down the oil.
Wash the clothes in the hottest water recommended for the fabric, using the recommended amount of heavy-duty laundry detergent.
Examine the stained area after washing.

info.note: Do not use a dryer until the stain is fully removed. Air-dry if unsure, as heat can set the stain permanently.

p.note: Act quickly to prevent oil stains from setting, as this makes them harder to remove.
Do not rub the stain without a cleaning solvent, as this can push oil deeper into the fabric.
Always confirm the stain is removed before using a dryer, as heat can make the stain permanent.
